comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I had trouble finding out exactly where this tunnel is. I think it is just north of the current rail tunnel, shown as a pale track on this GoogleSatellite photo - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Picton+NSW&hl=en&ll=-34... . I think the photo must be of the west end of the tunnel due to the locomotive's shadow on the right. It is confusing because the old original line of the railway was superseded in 1919. More here - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picton_%E2%80%93_Mittagong_loop_rai...

comment.author: 35603348@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  Yes this was taken from the western or country end of the tunnel.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/highplains68] Thanks for the confirmation! With all the loops, twists and turns near Picton, it is difficult to see which is 'town' and 'country'. The State Library of Victoria has a version of this image by William Hetzer dated 1866, ie this is before the tunnel's opening. Their copy includes the title -
Picton Tunnel Great Southern Railway New South Wales, 1866 John Whitton Esqr. Engineer in Chief for Railways
See - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/105685 (click on More Information for notes)

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06][http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia][http://www.flickr.com/photos/highplains68] Locomotive No 7 (Class 6 2-2-2 tender locomotive)  was ordered from the builder, William Fairbairn and Sons, on  3 November 1855 and entered service in April 1857 having arrived in Sydney on the 'Nourmahal' on 5 February 1857. The loco was condemned in 1881, and scrapped in 1885 having travelled 252,917 km.

(There were only two locomotives in the class Nos 6 & 7. No 6 was condemned in 1883 also being scrapped in 1885, having travelled 229,249 km)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Those are interesting statistics.  'No.7' did about 10,000 km per year,  which does not seem very much by today's standards.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You have to remember that the system was very much smaller then! Also the locomotives were replaced for mainline running in 1865 by the 23-class. At that point Nos 6 & 7 were relegated to Parramatta suburban services, Newtown locals and the Rookwood funeral trains. Then with the introduction of 67-class in 1875 they were withdrawn from suburban working altogether. No 6 then went to Goulburn as a shunter and No 7 operated Darling Harbour coal traffic. 

These little locomotives were the first to be placed in service after the Government had taken control of the NSW Railways.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Good points (no pun intended).  Thank you.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] This is the southern end of the tunnel. The northern portal can be seen on the left by anyone travelling on the main line. Interestingly the next tunnel "Redbank" after this "Picton" tunnel about 2 km toward Thirlmere has just been bypassed by a significant re-route of the main Southern Line around the hill due to Xstrata's Long Wall mine subsidence. Apparently XStrata paid for this but the old tunnel has been very meticulously erased by a huge landscaping effort and is now difficult to spot. This coincides with the relatively nearby Pheasant's Nest freeway viaduct being braced a few years ago due to the same mine subsidence.
Various monitoring points exist along both the freeway and the main southern line to monitor the problem. It will be a brave government who decides to proceed with a Very Fast Train if it is to pass anywhere within a 5 or 10 km radius. Recently the Wilton Airport proposal has been scrapped citing the region's ground instability.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Now I am confused again! When you say "southern" do you mean the 'country' end of the tunnel? A glance at the satellite image shows the country end further north than the town end - the old tunnel runs WNW-ESE. The modern-day photos of the entrance seem to be mostly of the 'town' end (I think), without these steep embankments - eg en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Picton_Mushroom_Tunnel.jpg

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes the Southern end is ESE The line travels west from Picton station and viaduct then almost does a full circle before entering the tunnel.Your photo reference "Mushroom Tunnel" is this end which can be seen travelling Southbound on the current main line just before it too enters it's newer tunnel. The old photo has enbankments on both sides and a straight track which is the clue for it being the Southern portal
I recall the land owner had problems a while back with loads of people visiting the tunnel. Anyone who might want to visit it might keep that in mind.

The reason I am familiar is that I travel 3 hours twice a day by train from Mittagong  ;-)

comment.author: 59513278@N04
comment._content:
Picton Fact,  The only town in Australia where the train passes through twice. 

You hear the trains coming up the hill from the viaduct saying: bugger Picton, bugger Picton, bugger Picton.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
This photo has concerned me for the last couple of weeks and I have changed my mind about which end this is. It is afterall the northwestern end (furthest from town),

However, contrary to logic, the train is actually coming from Picton!
The new tunnel on the main line runs parallel to the old tunnel but trains now travel in the opposite direction due to an almost 270 degree loop around the hill which sets them up to proceed South. This loop wasn't part of the "loop line" originally as then the trains entered the tunnel directly from the Picton viaduct before continuing West. During the years when the loop line operated limited rail motor services, it was re routed to run off the main line's loop after it's own tunnel was closed.
I hope the loops aren't too confusing.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jimmcgs]   love your comment...so true!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Sorry you have had sleepless nights over a spooky tunnel.  Yes, the "town" and "country" ends of the old and new tunnels are reversed.  All VERY confusing.  Great to get it cleared up.  How about a walk through in the dead of night ... ?

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
Haha yes! I did that once before somewhere else in pitch black without a torch.
I couldn't help thinking that there would be a deep pit I would fall into.
Might walk the length of the loop line sometime if I can find the time. (hidden joke..only you would understand)

comment.author: 92149981@N03
comment._content: Hi, just to add a bit confusion to the photo... The locomotive is NOT No.7 (Fairbairns). No.7 had cylinders on the outside of the frame as well as McConnell dome, funnel is slightly different too. Going through my notes... the closest I can come up with is No.17 (Robt.Stephenson) 0-6-0, B/No.1541/1864... though there are still discrepancies like the straight hand rail on the smoke box door.
